page.title: 10Trees
page.content: In 1965 according to the records of Much Hadham's Women's Institute, there were probably more elm trees than any other tree in Much Hadham. The elms were found in large numbers round the Playing Fields, at The Hill and Spindle Bridge.Then disaster struck in the late 1970's in the form of a little beetle and the Dutch Elm disease struck Britain. In a very short space of time all the elms disappeared from our countryside.David Bellamy, a famous conservationist, organised a scheme to replace our lost elm trees with disease resistant trees. Our school has purchased two of these trees for about Â£5. Although the elms have gone there is still The Lordship's Ash,which perpetuates the weather forecast for summer "ash before oak a regular soak, oak before ash,just a little splash".
